reviews:
no matter your religious preference, it is worth a stop to view this magnificent building on the inside and outside. It is very peaceful to sit down, take a rest from walking; and enjoy looking at the amazing stained glass, labyrinths and sculptures. It is right on the cable car route, so you can easily hop off and walk in to soak in all the beauty.

All of San Francisco is down hill from here
As gothic as it gets in the USA. Stop. Look. Then walk to the labyrinth on the right. Enter. Slow down. Breathe and listen to San Francisco all around you.

I've taken photos of this beautiful cathedral both during the day and at night. It's beautiful. It's got lots of great, contemporary art features if you pay attention and it also has a lot of quaint little gardens and flowers out in front. It's hard to miss if you are staying in Nobb Hill which is typically where I stay when I'm in San Francisco.

The Grace Cathedral is just beautiful. It is a great building with wonderful stained glass window. It is a peaceful church to sit down and enjoy the atmosphere. I went on a Sunday afternoon and had luck to hear an amazing organ player. It is easy to get there by Cable Car, the Californian line stops just in front of it.

Me and my husband come here often, it is just such a beautiful place to spend some free time. The music is wonderful, and the atmosphere is very peaceful.

A beautiful cathedral with some interesting history. We walked in on a Sunday and were greeted by a quartet opera performance in progress. This cathedral seems to have regular Sunday events! Worth a visit.

We were in San Franciso for a Company event and while there had some extra time. We went to see Grace Cathedral and were awe struck. The building was beautiful. While there, the pianist came in (I'm guessing to practice for Sunday Eucharist) and the pipe organ was just amazing. Almost made us want to stay for Sunday just to listen to that.

There is also one outside, but the inside labyrinth seems more intimate because the church is so quiet and peaceful. It's a wonderful place to go to pray or think. Beautifuly kept Cathedral in the heart of Nob Hill. FREE! Although donations are gratefully accepted. NIce art installations, and the stained glass is a beautiful as Notre Dame.

Beautiful building. We arrived as evensong was about to begin, but we were still given a warm welcome when we explained we were only there for a look around. Some beautiful artwork and architecture, so you are likely to enjoy it whether you are a Christian or not.

Wow! This place is HUGE and magical. I love to photograph historic Churches and this one does not disappoint.

Grace Cathedral is a very stately church. The concerts are always terrific. No matter your beliefs, treat yourself to either the indoor or the outdoor labyrinth. So peaceful! There's a reason people from many different cultures have built and walked labyrinths for millenia. You will not regret it. And great views of SF from Nob Hill.

Similar to Notre Dame in Paris but smaller

Near the Fairmount Hotel and 'Top of the Mark' Grace cathedral has a similar external look to Notre Dame in Paris with its two towers and central spire.
Outside the bronze and golden 'Gates of Paradise' doors are made from a cast taken from the original doors in the Florence Baptistry designed by Lorenzo Ghiberti are magnificent.
Inside the labryinth on the floor, the murals including the 1906 earthquake mural, stained glass windows including one celebrating Albert Einstein and one called the 'Gift' which depicts the Milky way set within a cloaked human figure, and the Rose window, even a memorial to Winston Churchill. All of this and the peacefulness inside make this a very worthwhile visit.

I love Grace Cathedral for faith and beauty, must go! If you are episcopal or catholic or just faithful, you must visit. It is on the top of Nob Hill and I love being there. I like the Sunday 6pm service but up to you what works for you. They also do yoga on Tuesday nights which is very popular!

This cathedral is modelled on the Notre Dame Cathedral in Paris. Grace Cathedral is a fine building but do not expect it to be quite like any of the beautiful medieval cathedrals of Europe. For a start, it is small in comparison.
Grace Cathedral sits on a commanding site at the top of Nob Hill. If you are walking, it is a real climb but the California Street Cable Car takes you right to the Cathedral.
Outside, there is an impressive view of the towers from Huntington Park and then cross the road and enter via the east end. Here there are Ghiberti doors which are reproductions of the doors of the Florence Baptistery. also, before you go in, visit and walk the outside labyrinth which is just to the right of the entrance.
Inside, the Cathedral is bathed with blue light from the stained glass windows and there is an uninterrupted view up to the high altar. As you go in, you immediately encounter a second labyrinth.
The modern stained glass windows are really quite beautiful and when we visited, there was a light installation representing Jacob's Ladder called Jacob's Dream.
We attended Choral Evensong in the Grace Chapel. Although a lovely service, it was no patch on the uplifting, beautiful Choral Evensong services that are characteristic of the Anglican Tradition and sung in all English Cathedrals.
Downstairs, the cathedral does have restrooms, a coffee bar and a small souvenir shop.

Grace Cathedral, the principal Episcopal church in San Francisco, is located on the top of Nob Hill. It was begun in the early 1900s and is a beautiful example of Gothic architecture. All the windows are stained and the walls are generally decorated with mid-century murals detailing the history and peoples of the area. Many nice architectural details. Chapel of Grace to the left of the altar at the crossing is a beautiful miniature version of the Gothic style.

On top of yet another SF hill. Mock Gothic in te European tradition. Note the doors (copy of Florence), the labyrinth, stained glass telling the story. Oasis of calm, even when preparing for 100 people doing yoga! Services regularly with good choir.

As a concert hall, the acoustics are awful

This review is only about Grace Cathedral as a concert hall. Yes, it's a gorgeous piece of architecture; take the tour! And come to services, and just sit and get in touch with your meditative side. But if you come here for a concert, be prepared to be disappointed. I came to hear the SF Gay Men's Chorus and the Oakland Interfaith Gospel Choir -- both huge groups with big sound, and I never thought they'd meet a hall they'd get swallowed up in, but even with microphones Grace Cathedral absolutely muted them. Huge disappointment for us in the 15th row; I can't imagine what the sound was like way in the back.

I am an atheist but Cathedrals are often fascinating places to visit. This is no exception. As a European, I am used to Cathedrals that have a long history and date back from very different times. Being a young country, American cathedrals are different and Grace Cathedral, despite the traditional architectural style, is actually a pretty modern building. Construction started in 1927 and was largely completed in 1964. It combines old and new with stained glass windows depicting copies of ancient European glass and astronaut John Glenn, for instance.

The Cathedral reflects a rather different view of life and religion and actively welcomes people of different faiths and none. It has been used by many key historical figures to give their messages to the people with Martin Luther King, Desmond Tutu and the Dalai Lama all having preached here. It has an AIDS interfaith chapel. It is an interesting place and provides an oasis of tranquillity to reflect on where this chaotic society is headed.

Heavenly Treasure in San Francisco - Jacob's Dream a Luminous Path

Grace Cathedral was a couple of blocks from my hotel and I went early to take a peak inside. This cathedral quickly transports you to medieval style European cathedrals, with the climbing concrete arches, artistic stained glass windows and recessed sanctuary, typical of Episcopalian style churches.

Upon climbing the steps you will see the golden door complete with tin stamping of the history of the founders. Inside the baptismal font is at the back, near a labrynth for walking meditation for prayer. The morning sun came through the artistic stained glass windows making a pattern on the floor and drawing attention to the wall murals which tell the history of California, the missions and founding peoples of this church.

This church was very ecumenical - it had an open chapel area devoted to Mary and an arched hallway beside with small candle lit prayer kneelers, along a hallway reminiscent of a castle walk way, with hanging tapestries and a feeling that King Arthur would walk through at any moment.

One chapel that moved me was the chapel dedicated to those who have passed from Aids - with the religious symbol for every denomination on earth, to all those lives who have been touched by this tragedy. There one could light a candle and spend time in prayer for lives lost.

The artists in residence had a hanging luminated ladder - Jacob's Dream a Luminous Path hanging in the church. The lights shining from the stained glass really brought it to life, but until i looked at it from the other side that is what moved me the most. The light showed a pattern of souls walking down the ladder to greet the souls coming up the ladder - it was breathtaking and perhaps the most moving experience to see this work of art. Took my breath away.

Also - there is another meditation labrynth outside of the church as well. Parishoners were meeting there as friends and walking it together - beautiful. Inspiring

Grace Cathedral is a must see - next time I will be there for a church service. No entry fee, just request a donation.

During our visit, we were thrilled to experience "Jacob’s Dream: A Luminous Path", which is an installation of light and moving images designed to evoke a pathway between earth and heaven, between the visible and invisible. To find such a work, inside an already famous Episcopal cathedral was exciting. The cathedral is known for its mosaics by Jan Henryk De Rosen, a replica of Ghiberti's Gates of Paradise, two labyrinths, varied stained glass windows, Keith Haring's AIDS Chapel altarpiece, medieval and contemporary furnishings, as well as its forty-four bell carillon, three organs, and choirs. You can be a student of architectural and/or civic history when you visit, or you can just walk the labyrinth and contemplate. When you visit, you will not be disappointed; you may even find out more about yourself and who you really are. For a small donation ($0.25), you can purchase postcards of the cathedral, its current art installations etc., far below what you'd pay at local markets or gift shops.

"Grace" is the perfect name for such a stunning cathedral!

Grace is the perfect name for such a stunning cathedral! From its architectural beauty to its mission of being an "open and accepting" community this is a must on any trip to San Francisco. The current cathedral is descended from Grace chapel which was founded in the year of the gold rush; 1849. From there it has been rebuilt after the 1906 earthquake and the current building was begun in 1927 and finished in 1964. This cathedral was built in the French Gothic style by architect Lewis Hobart.

Start by climbing the imposing steps to the front doors of this majestic cathedral and see the "Doors of Paradise" which were molded from Ghiberti's Baptistery doors of the Duomo in Florence, Italy. From here, enter and pick up a brochure from one of the docents at the information desk. In front of the information desk is an inlaid Labyrinth; one of two that can be found at the cathedral (the other can be found in the outdoor courtyard). Next, head to the AIDS Memorial Chapel which holds a rotating portion of the "AIDS quilt", tritych alterpiece by artist Keith Haring, and the symbols from many world religions.

From here head down the nave and look at the wonderful murals which depict San Francisco city history (notably the 1906 fire). Also look up to the majestic stained glass windows which have a range of biblical, social, and also scientific themes. Look for the Einstein window and the "universe" window! Walk up to the front of the cathedral and look at the various pieces of art in the cloisters and notable the pulpit which has hosted the likes of the Dali Lama, Doctor Jane Goodall, Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr., presidents and Desmond Tutu.

Check out the website or ask a docent for a schedule of choral and evening song worship to be able to hear the majestic organ and Grace choir. Last and not least, make sure that you visit the gift store (the staff was extremely friendly) and cafe on the ground level for some mementos and interesting gifts!
